title: Sherpas have completed fixing ropes to the summit of Mount Everest. Climbers can now safely ascend the mountain using these ropes.
content:
The rope has been fixed up to Mount Everest for the spring climbing season. Seven Summit Treks did this, and 10 climbers were involved.

Permission has been granted for 30 mountains, including Everest, with 956 people approved to climb. They include 200 women and 756 men.

The government has collected over 67 crore rupees from climbers.

With the rope fixed, the climbing route is now open for domestic and foreign mountaineers with permission.
summary: Seven Summit Treks Company completed rope fixing up to Mount Everest's peak, officially opening the 2024 spring climbing season for 956 permitted climbers.

title: Meeting of Parliament adjourned over protests from the opposition party.
content: Nepali Congress protested the House of Representatives meeting, demanding an investigation into misappropriated cooperative funds. They blocked Home Affairs Minister Rabi Lamichhane from speaking despite the Speaker's request. As a result, the meeting was adjourned until May 14 at 6 pm.
summary: Opposition Nepali Congress (NC) obstructed two House of Representatives (HoR) meetings, demanding a parliamentary probe into cooperative fund misappropriation, leading to the meetings' adjournment; the next HoR meeting is scheduled for May 14.

title: Private businesses ask Prime Minister for help so that regular flights can resume at Gia Lai Airport.
content: Bhairahawa's private sector wants Prime Minister Dahal's help in starting regular flights at Gautam Buddha International Airport. They told him that this is important for the area's economy. Prime Minister Dahal said he would look into it and that plans were already in place to start regular flights.
summary: Bhairahawa's private sector requests Prime Minister Dahal's support for regular flights at Gautam Buddha International Airport, which he acknowledges positively.

title: National Assembly meeting postponed due to protest by the National Council.
content: Second National Assembly meeting postponed due to protest from opposition lawmakers. They demand a parliamentary investigation into alleged embezzlement in cooperatives before allowing the Assembly to continue its work.
summary: The second National Assembly meeting was postponed without progress due to opposition NC's protest, demanding a probe into alleged cooperative deposit embezzlement.

title: Today marks the final day of the Maha Kumbh Mela, a grand religious festival in India.
content:
The 12-year Pindeshwar Poorna Mahakumbha Mela, held in Chatradham, Sunsari, ends today. People from Nepal and abroad attended the month-long event.

Chatradham, known as ancient Haridwar, has hosted the Kumbha Mela since 2059 AD. It holds Ardha Kumbha Mela every 6 years and Purn Kumbha Mela every 12 years.

The Kumbha Mela is also held in four holy cities in India. According to Hindu scriptures, the Saptakoshi river in Barahkshetra and Pindeshwardham in Sunsari are linked to the Kumbha Mela.
summary: The ongoing Pindeshwar Poorna Mahakumbha Mela, a month-long religious festival held in Barahkshetra Municipality-1, Sunsari, Nepal, concludes today, having attracted attendees from across the country and abroad.

title: Gold price has increased by Rs. 2,300 per tola.
content: Gold rose by Rs 2,300 per tola to Rs 137,900. Silver also went up by Rs 50 per tola to Rs 1,735.
summary: Gold prices surge in Nepal by Rs 2,300 per tola, while silver gains Rs 50.

title: Rhino conservation faces challenges: 21 rhinos killed in 10 months.
content:
In the past 10 months, 21 rhinos have died near Chitwan National Park.
- 2 were killed by poachers, 19 died naturally (stuck in swamps, fighting, etc.).
- The park is managing wetlands and grasslands to help rhinos survive.
- There are currently 694 rhinos in the park, and some have been moved to the eastern region to manage their habitat.
summary: In the past 10 months, 21 rhinos died in Chitwan National Park, two from poaching and 19 from natural causes, including habitat-related deaths, sparking conservation efforts to manage grasslands and wetlands.

title: European Union will assist Nepal in attracting foreign investment.
content:
**EU to Help Nepal Attract Investment**

The European Union (EU) will assist Nepal in attracting investment from European companies. The 'EU-Nepal Trade Forum' will be held in Kathmandu from May 15-16 to discuss investment opportunities in Nepal.

The EU aims to support Nepal's goal of graduating from the least developed country status by 2026, by creating jobs and economic growth.
summary: The European Union plans to host a trade forum in Nepal to attract European investments, supporting Nepal's economic development and job creation goals.

title: Swiss government will provide 9.01 million Swiss francs for tourism projects.
content:
**Switzerland gives $9 million to Nepal for trekking tourism**

Nepal and Switzerland signed an agreement for a four-year trekking tourism project. The project will help 100,000 locals in 29 areas of Koshi Province. It will support local art, culture, production, and jobs, and promote sustainable tourism. The project aims to boost tourism in Koshi Province and increase income for locals through eco-tourism.
summary: Switzerland provides 9 million Swiss francs for a four-year trekking tourism project in Nepal's Koshi Province, targeting 100,000 locals and supporting conservation, employment, and sustainable tourism development.

content: Two men from Rupandehi were arrested by the Valley Crime Investigation Office in Kathmandu with Rs 9.8 lakh. Samir Sunar, 28, and Milan, 29, from Siyari Rural Municipality were detained on Friday.
summary: Police arrested Samir Sunar and Milan, both from Rupandehi, with an undisclosed amount of Rs 9.8 lakh from Kathmandu.

title: Four people arrested for leaking Grade 12 exam papers.
content: Police in Kathmandu arrested four people for writing leaked Grade 12 computer science answer sheets. The suspects were caught at a party hall in Kathmandu. Police are investigating the incident.
summary: Kathmandu police arrested four individuals for possessing leaked Grade 12 answer sheets, hindering the scheduled exam.

title: Arrest warrants issued for 20 people, including former officials, related to the Bal Mandir case.
content: Arrest warrant issued for 20 people, including past Bal Mandir officials, for illegally using and leasing charity land in Kathmandu.
summary: Nepal Police's CIB issues arrest warrant for 20 ex-officials of Bal Mandir charity and business members over land embezzlement.

title: President attends Law Day celebration, highlighting rule of law and justice.
content:
On Wednesday, Nepal celebrated Law Day 2081 BS. The Supreme Court hosted a program with the President, Prime Minister, and other officials in attendance.

Chief Justice Bishwambhar Prasad Shrestha congratulated citizens and stressed the importance of establishing a fair society with guaranteed rights and rule of law. He emphasized the need for collaboration between the judiciary, Attorney General's Office, and Nepal Bar Association to ensure effective justice.

Law Day commemorates the introduction of the Chief Court Act in 2008 BS, which brought about judicial reforms and established the principles of rule of law and separation of powers.

The event was attended by high-ranking officials including Vice President Ram Sahay Prasad Yadav, Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda,' and others.
summary: On Law Day 2081 BS, the Supreme Court hosted a program attended by dignitaries, including the President, to commemorate the introduction of the Chief Court Act in 2008 BS and recognize the importance of rule of law and judicial reform.

title: Joshi Dhakal has been promoted to Assistant Inspector General (AIG) in the Nepal Police. The decision was made at a cabinet meeting.
content:
**Government Updates:**

- Two police officers, Umesh Joshi and Bhim Dhakal, have been promoted to Additional Inspectors General.
- 42 athletes who won medals in international sports have been honored.
- Nanda Majhi has been named Vice Chairman of the Social Welfare Council.
- Suresh Manandhar has become a Member of the Language Commission.
summary: Nepal Police Deputy Inspectors General Umesh Raj Joshi and Bhim Prasad Dhakal promoted to Additional Inspectors General, 42 athletes honored, Nanda Lal Majhi named Social Welfare Council Vice Chairman, and Suresh Manandhar appointed Language Commission Member.

title: Construction of a bridge along the Narayangadh-Muglin road section is underway.
content:
**Narayangadh-Muglin Road Bridges**

11 of 15 bridges are now open.

4 bridges are being built:
* Khahare
* Namche
* Kalikhola
* Tuin Khola

Khahare and Namche bridges should open by mid-July.

Tuin Khola bridge will open by mid-November.

These bridges were delayed due to construction challenges and compensation issues.

The road is safer now because of the new and improved bridges.
summary: Construction on 15 bridges along the Narayangadh-Muglin road is in full swing, with 11 already operational and the remaining 4 expected to be completed by mid-November.

title: Lightning and forest fires have killed 27 people in the last 24 days.
content: In the past 24 days, 27 people have died in fires and lightning strikes in Nepal. NDRRMA has approved financial aid for families to build temporary shelters, as they did for Gorkha earthquake victims.
summary: Between April 13 and May 6, 27 individuals died in Nepal due to fire, forest fire, and lightning strikes, prompting the NDRRMA to approve financial aid for victims' families in building temporary shelters.

title: Prime Minister inaugurates the breakthrough of the Sunkoshi Marin Diversion Tunnel, a crucial part of the Marin Hydropower Project. This tunnel will divert water from the Sunkoshi River to the Marin Reservoir, creating a continuous water flow for hydropower generation.
content:
**Sunkoshi Tunnel Breakthrough**

Prime Minister Prachanda opened a 13.3 km tunnel, built in 19 months. The tunnel will divert water from the Sunkoshi River to generate electricity and provide irrigation for five districts in the Madhes region.

The tunnel, dug by a Chinese company, cost Rs 10 billion to build. It uses advanced technology to withstand landslides and mudslides.

The project is expected to produce 31 megawatts of electricity and irrigate 122,000 hectares of land.
summary: Prime Minister Prachanda inaugurated the breakthrough of the 13.3-kilometer tunnel for the Sunkoshi-Marin Diversion Project, aiming to provide irrigation and electricity to five districts in Madhes.

title: Nepali Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal has assured support in bringing back Nepalis currently serving in the Russian army. He has promised to take diplomatic measures to facilitate their return to Nepal.
content: Prime Minister Dahal promised to use diplomacy to bring back Nepalis fighting in the Russian army. He met with their families and assured them of his commitment to help.
summary: PM Dahal commits diplomatic initiatives to repatriate Nepalis serving in the Russian Army after meeting with their families.

title: Federal Parliament's budget meeting starts today.
content: The budget session of Nepal's parliament is starting today. President Ramchandra Paudel called the session, which begins at 2pm. The government will present its budget for the next year on May 28th. Before then, the President will share the government's annual plans. The Speaker of the parliament, Devraj Ghimire, has met with leaders of political parties to plan for the session.
summary: The budget session of Nepal's federal parliament commenced today as mandated by the constitution, with the president scheduled to present the government's annual policy and program and the estimated budget for the upcoming year.

title: Government ignores key opposition concerns, angering opposition leader Lekhak.
content:
The Nepali Congress, a major opposition party, is demanding an investigation into alleged embezzlement of money in cooperatives. They want action taken against those responsible, as the money belongs to ordinary people.

The party stresses the need to clean up the cooperative sector, which is important for the economy. However, they are not interested in forming a new government with the CPN UML.

Instead, they want to work with all major political parties to address people's needs and make sure parliament is effective in representing their voices.
summary: The Nepali Congress demands an investigation into cooperative fraud, while emphasizing parliament's importance and the need for consensus among political parties.

title: JSP Nepal to explore legal action.
content: Janata Samajwadi Party (JSP) led by Upendra Yadav will take legal action over a party split. A faction led by Ashok Rai created a new party, which the Election Commission recognized. JSP plans to meet on Wednesday to discuss the split and decide on legal action. A press conference will be held after the meeting to announce JSP's official position.
summary: Janata Samajwadi Party (JSP) to pursue legal recourse after a faction led by Ashok Rai received recognition as a new party by the Election Commission of Nepal.

title: Oli sees a need for unity among leftist parties
content: Former Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli urges all left-wing parties to unite with the CPN (UML). He believes this unity will help the party achieve its goal of winning a majority in the upcoming parliamentary election. Oli remembers the late politician Siddinath Gyawali and highlights his tireless efforts for positive change. CPN Unity National Campaign Chairperson Bam Dev Gautam expresses interest in joining the CPN (UML).
summary: CPN (UML) leader KP Sharma Oli calls for leftist unity, aiming for success in the 2084 BS parliamentary election, while honoring the late Siddinath Gyawali's integrity and dedication to the nation.

title: Minister Joshi calls for urgent support to provide shelter for earthquake survivors in Jajarkot.
content:
**Minister Joshi's Speech on Earthquake Relief**

Minister Joshi spoke about the importance of providing shelter to those who lost their homes in the November earthquake. He emphasized the need for quick compensation to help them build temporary homes before the rainy season.

He also highlighted the need to address ongoing disasters, such as landslides and floods, and stressed the role of disaster management authorities in reducing risks.

Despite partnerships between federal, provincial, and local governments, financial constraints are limiting the effectiveness of relief efforts. The government aims to rebuild over 100,000 houses in Karnali Province, which was severely affected by the earthquake.
summary: Minister Joshi emphasizes the urgent need for shelter and compensation for Jajarkot earthquake victims, as Nepal faces ongoing disasters and requires improved disaster management policies.

title: A mother and son tragically lost their lives in a house fire, their bodies charred.
content: Mother and son died in a house fire while trying to put out a forest fire. The mother caught fire while protecting hay, and the son died trying to save her. Police are investigating, and more details are pending. Forest fires are still burning in the area.
summary: Mother and son perish in Beteni community forest fire while attempting to extinguish it.

content:
**Road Accident in Dadeldhura Kills Two**

Two men died and two others were injured in a tractor accident last night.

The deceased are:

* Dhiraj Thapamgar, 40, tractor driver
* Bishnu BK, 27

The injured are:

* Sudeep BK, 31

They are being treated at a local hospital.
summary: A road accident involving a tractor in Dadeldhura claimed the lives of two individuals, injuring two others.

title: 24 artifacts shipped from Hawaii to Nepal.
content:
The US Embassy returned 24 artifacts to Nepal, dating from the 13th to 18th centuries. They were donated by Ms. Susan Bradford.

The Embassy has worked to recover stolen or lost Nepalese artifacts, returning 63 items in the past year. They thank Ms. Bradford for her donation and hope it inspires others to return artifacts to their rightful owners.
summary: Nepal Embassy in Washington, DC repatriated 24 ancient artifacts from private collection in Hawaii to the Department of Archaeology, Nepal.

title: Kanti Highway closed due to landslide
content: A landslide in Kalche has blocked the Kanti Highway. The road is closed until further notice due to damage to the gabion wall, which prevents vehicles from passing through.
summary: Landslide on Kanti Highway near Lalitpur disrupts vehicular movement due to collapsed gabion wall.

title: An elderly couple tragically died in a house fire.
content: An elderly couple, Tej Bahadur Lama and Thuli Lama, died in a house fire in Dhading. The fire broke out around 11:30pm, and everything in the house was destroyed. When police arrived, the couple was already dead.
summary: Fire kills elderly couple Tej Bahadur Lama and Thuli Lama in Thakre rural municipality, Dhading, destroying their home, food, and clothes.

title:
**HWPL Statement on Israel-Iran Conflict**

HWPL, a global peace organization, calls for an immediate end to violence between Israel and Iran.

* Expresses deep concern over the escalating tensions and potential for further conflict.
* Urges both sides to exercise restraint and engage in dialogue.
* Emphasizes the need for a peaceful resolution based on justice and mutual respect.
* Calls for international cooperation to prevent further violence and promote stability.
content:
**Iran-Israel Conflict**

Iran and Israel are fighting, using powerful weapons and killing people.

**Casualties and Concerns**

Thousands of civilians have died in the Israel-Hamas conflict. The international community is worried that the fighting could spread into a bigger war.

**Calls for Peace**

HWPL and other organizations are asking Iran and Israel to stop fighting and talk to each other to make peace.

**Recommendations**

Countries should help Iran and Israel make friends and provide aid to people in need. An international law for peace is needed to prevent future wars. HWPL will continue to work for peace.
summary:
The recent violent conflict between Iran and Israel is causing significant concerns in the international community. The two nations that do not share borders are mobilizing high-end weaponry to attack each other and kill human lives.1 April 2024, the Israeli military attacked the Iranian consulate in Syria. A strike against a non-military facility in a third nation, a nation not directly involved in the conflict, infringes international law and constitutes a war crime. Moreover, on 13 April, Iran responded by attacking Israel’s land. Both nations have pointed their guns directly at each other, and there are growing concerns in the international community that the attacks could escalate into another war.
The Israel-Hamas War in Gaza has killed 30,000 since last year, and news outlets reported on dire situations in Gaza, running out of space for proper burial. The war that has persisted in the region over the past century continuously overshadows the prospect of the coexistence of the human race.
It is a clear indication that the greatest victims of war are innocent civilians. How could those lost lives ever be brought back? What could compensate for the outcry of children and the anguish of the youth in devastated dwellings?
HWPL strongly supports the voices of the citizens, the true protagonists of the global village, who oppose war and call for peace. All nations of the global community must uphold the citizens’ demands, thereby ceasing the unjust war and joining to accomplish peace. Organizations worldwide, in alliance with HWPL as peace solidarity, urge Iran and Israel to put a stop to the acts of aggression immediately and to come forward for conversations to usher in peace.
HWPL recommend that the international community take necessary measures to facilitate the formation of amicable relations between the two nations and provide humanitarian aid. It would be reasonable for all countries to support an international legal instrument for peace that embodies the long-yearned path to peace and to comply with its contents so that we leave a legacy of peace for future generations. HWPL will not spare its efforts for peace and cessation of wars.

title: Nepal and Korea are preparing for a high-level visit. This involves planning security, transportation, accommodations, and other arrangements to ensure a successful visit.
content: Preparations are underway to mark 50 years of diplomatic relations between Nepal and South Korea. High-level visits, events, and investments are planned. South Korea is Nepal's fourth largest investor, and is looking to invest more in hydroelectricity. Nepal is a priority partner for South Korea, and many Nepali workers go to Korea. Nepalis are now involved in service and forestry sectors, in addition to agriculture and production.
summary: Nepal and South Korea to mark 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations with high-level visits, investment announcements, and expansion in labor destinations for Nepali workers.

title: Japan and Nepal have many similarities, says Japan's Foreign Minister, Kamikawa Yoko.
content:
**Japan and Nepal: Similarities and Shared Challenges**

* Japan and Nepal have many mountains, making nation-building difficult.
* Both countries are democracies and have supported each other's democratic efforts.
* Japan and Nepal have experienced devastating earthquakes and have helped each other in times of need.
* Both countries have limited natural resources and value international cooperation.

**Japan's Support for Nepal's Development**

* Japan has provided assistance in infrastructure, agriculture, education, and healthcare.
* The Nagdhunga tunnel will improve transportation and support Nepal's economic growth.
* Japan supports Nepal's efforts to promote gender equality and peace through the "Women, Peace and Security" initiative.

**Deepening Bilateral Ties**

* The number of Nepalis living in Japan has increased significantly.
* Japan-Nepal diplomatic relations will celebrate 70 years in 2026.
* Japan will continue to support Nepal after it graduates from the Least Developed Country category.
summary: Japan and Nepal share mountainous terrain, democratic values, and a history marked by earthquakes, leading to mutual support and assistance, including infrastructure development, education, healthcare, and cooperation in "Women, Peace and Security."

title: Don't seek foreign employment through illegal means.
content:
The Embassy of Nepal in Islamabad has urged all the concerned to only use legal means to go for foreign employment, noting many Nepali have been victimized and stranded in Kyrgyzstan for some time on temptation of attractive jobs.The embassy said it has received information that some of those victimized have been assured to be sent to other countries using Kyrgyzstan route, sharing that some of the stranded people have been rescued and sent back to Nepal, some are on their way back but the process of reaching there has not stopped.
In a statement issued on Tuesday, the embassy said, "As per the information received, some Nepali and foreigners are being involved in the fraudulent acts in the face of lucrative jobs".
Individuals and groups involved in illegal activities of taking Nepali citizens abroad on the wrong temptation and leaving them stranded have to face the prevailing law, the statement further noted.
"The embassy sincerely requests all concerned not to fall prey to the ill-intended act of fraudulent groups and to use only the established and legal route arranged by the Government of Nepal to go for foreign employment", the statement reads.
summary: Nepali Embassy in Islamabad urges against illegal foreign employment amid victimizations in Kyrgyzstan.

title: Ohio doctor couple supports strengthening ties between Nepal and the United States.
content:
**During the COVID-19 pandemic:**

* Dr. Poudel and Dr. Mahato provided medical help to Nepali Americans in the US.
* Dr. Poudel advocated for sending vaccines to Nepal, resulting in Nepal receiving vaccines from the US.

* Recognized for his work by the City of Reynoldsburg and Senator Brown's office.
* Provides free medical care to low-income Nepali patients.
* Emphasizes the importance of healthy eating and exercise to prevent obesity.
* Connects US officials with local Nepali representatives.
* Facilitates collaborations between Nepali and American institutions for research and innovation.
* Promotes US-Nepal relations through the Nepal Caucus in the US Congress.
* Holds various leadership positions in Nepali American organizations.
summary: Dr. Damodar Poudel and Dr. Sanju Mahato provided life-saving medical services to Nepali communities in the US during COVID-19, lobbied for vaccine donations to Nepal, and facilitated collaborations between Nepal and the US in various sectors, including health, trade, and education.

title:
Officials from Nepal and Malaysia met to discuss:

* Strengthening trade and investment
* Collaboration in health and education
* Cooperation on tourism and cultural exchange
* Enhancing air connectivity
* Addressing climate change and disaster management

Nepal and Malaysia met to:

- Trade and tourism between the two countries are growing.
- Malaysia respects Nepal's Gurkha soldiers for their help in the past.
- Since 2001, Nepalese people have been able to work in Malaysia, which has strengthened their relationship.

summary: Nepalese Ambassador Dilli Raj Poudel met with Malaysian Immigration Director General Dato' Ruslin bin Jusoh to enhance cooperation and strengthen relations between Nepal and Malaysia.

title: Nepal's government is committed to making it easier and safer for businesses to invest in the country.
content:
**Government to Boost Economy**

Prime Minister Prachanda promises to support investors to strengthen Nepal's economy. A new Hyundai Motor plant will create jobs, reduce imports, and use local resources and electricity. The government is making changes to laws and policies to make it easier for businesses to invest and create more employment.
summary: Prime Minister Prachanda inaugurated the Hyundai Motor Assembling Plant in Nawalparasi, emphasizing economic transformation and private sector collaboration.

title: Transparency and good governance support each other. Transparency promotes accountability and trust, while good governance ensures resources are used effectively and fairly. Together, they create a positive cycle of checks and balances that benefits everyone.
content:
**Transparency and Good Governance**

President Paudel emphasized that transparency and good governance go hand in hand. He commended auditors as "economic watchdogs" for their vital role in ensuring accountable and transparent financial practices.

**Importance of Auditors**

Auditors play a crucial role in preventing fraud, ensuring accurate accounting, and maintaining transparency in economic activities. They contribute to the credibility of a country's financial system, making it attractive for assistance from other nations.

**Role of Skilled Auditors**

Skilled and knowledgeable auditors are essential for ensuring transparency and accountability in government agencies and businesses. They can prevent misuse of funds and promote financial stability.

**Conference Aims**

The National Conference on chartered accountancy aims to address the economic crisis facing Nepal and discuss solutions. It will also highlight the role of accountants in fostering economic development.
summary: President Paudel emphasizes transparency and good governance, highlighting the crucial role of auditors in maintaining economic security, preventing fraud, and promoting accountability in agencies.

title: Prime Minister Dahal plans to present the upcoming budget in a new way.
content: Prime Minister Prachanda plans to introduce new policies that focus on improving the economy, especially for those who are struggling financially. He will seek input from various parties to make the policies more people-oriented. The government is also working to promote good governance and fight corruption. Nepal's international relations are also being strengthened through high-level visits.
summary: Prime Minister Dahal announced the upcoming budget will target economic equality, solicit public input, and prioritize good governance while showcasing Nepal's diplomatic growth.

title:
**Nepal Swadeshi Summit 2024 Declaration**

The summit issued a 35-point declaration, calling for:

* Promotion of domestic industries
* Emphasis on agriculture and rural development
* Reduction of imports
* Increased use of local products
* Investment in research and innovation
* Support for small and medium-sized enterprises
* Encouragement of entrepreneurship and job creation
content:
**Make in Nepal Summit 2024 Declaration**

**Goals:**
* Empower local industries
* Increase domestic production
* Encourage consumption of Nepali products

**Key Points:**
* Reform laws to support industries
* Establish a specialized financial institution for industrial investments
* Prioritize domestic products for government purchases
* Ensure easy supply of raw materials
* Differentiate customs rates for finished goods and raw materials
* Implement One Stop Service Center
* Encourage production and import of competitive domestic products
* Fine industrialists instead of criminal charges
* Create a separate Act to regulate the industrial sector
* Review trade and investment agreements
* Promote consensus among political parties for economic stability
summary: The 'Make in Nepal-Swadheshi Summit-2024' concluded with a 35-point declaration promoting domestic industry, encouraging local production, and incentivizing consumer consumption of indigenous products.

title: Economic prosperity in Dailekh will spark prosperity in Nepal, says Minister Bhandari.
content:
Nepal's government hopes to find oil and gas in Dailekh district, which could boost the economy and make Dailekh a major economic hub.

The final drilling phase has started, and it's expected to take six months to finish. The government will then decide if the oil and gas found can be used, which could lead to processing facilities being built.

The Chinese government gave Nepal 2.5 billion rupees to help with the exploration, which is a collaboration between the two countries.
summary: In Dailekh, Minister Bhandari inaugurates final petroleum exploration, potentially leading to economic prosperity for the district.

title: Nepalese runners won two titles in Malaysia.
content:
Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal won two races in Malaysia:

* **Today:** First place in 21 km half marathon, with a time of 1:14:48 seconds
* **Yesterday:** First place in 21 km Climbathon, with a time of 3:03:58 seconds

Rijal was also the 8th Tower Runner in 2023, finishing a race with 83 flights of stairs in 9 minutes and 22 seconds.

Rijal is from Beni, Nepal, and has been running in Malaysia since he moved there five years ago.
summary: Nepali runner Mahadev Rijal claimed consecutive victories in Malaysia, winning the 21 km half marathon today and the 21 km Climbathon event yesterday, becoming the first to complete both events in the competition.

title: Nepal defeated West Indies A in the final match of a T20 series.
content:
**Nepal Defeats West Indies 'A' in T20 Series**

Nepal won the final T20 match against West Indies 'A' by six wickets. West Indies 'A' had won the first three matches.

**Nepal's Turnaround**

Nepal reached their target of 173 with 1.1 overs to spare. Kushal Malla (37 not out) and Anil Shah (58) led Nepal's chase.

**West Indies' Performance**

West Indies 'A' scored 172 runs in their innings, with Alick Athanaze scoring 42 runs. Sompal Kami and Sagar Dhakal took three wickets each for Nepal.
summary: Nepal defeated West Indies 'A' by six wickets in the final match of T20 Series, despite losing three consecutive matches previously.

title: President sends well wishes to cricket team.
content: President Paudel wished Nepali cricket players well in the ICC T20 World Cup. The tournament starts June 1st in the West Indies and US. Nepal is in Group D with South Africa, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and the Netherlands. Nepal's first match is against the Netherlands on June 4th.
summary: President Paudel extends best wishes to Nepali cricket players participating in the ICC T20 World Cup, starting June 1st, with Nepal placed in Group D facing Netherlands, South Africa, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh.

title: West Indies team A won the Twenty20 series by defeating another team in the final match.
content:
West Indies 'A' team has won the T20 series against Nepal, leading 3-1 with one match remaining. They defeated Nepal by 28 runs in the fourth match.

Andre Fletcher scored the most runs for West Indies 'A' (84), while Rohit Kumar Paudel scored the most runs for Nepal (82).

Hayden Walsh, Matthew Forde, Fabian Allen, and Gudakesh Motie all took multiple wickets for West Indies 'A'.

The final match of the series will be played on Saturday.
summary: West Indies 'A' clinched the T20 series against Nepal, leading 3-1 after defeating them by 28 runs in the fourth match.

title: Nepal lost their third match in the T20 series against West Indies by 76 runs.
content: Nepal lost to West Indies 'A' in the third T20 by 76 runs. Nepal tried to chase 228 runs but could only make 151. Karan KC and Lokesh Bam both scored 28 for Nepal. Johnson Charles scored 119 for West Indies. Nepal has won two and lost two matches in the five-match series.
summary: Nepal lost to West Indies 'A' by 76 runs in the third T20 match, despite Johnson Charles' century for the West Indies, with Nepal now holding a 2-1 record in the five-match series.

content:
Nepal's athletics team left for Dubai for Asian U-20 Championships.

Team members:

* Badal Karki (800m and 1500m)
* Adeshkumar Yadav (100m and 200m)
* Ajay B.K. (1500m and 3000m)

Coach: Kanti Mahato

title: Dengue cases in Bagmati province have crossed 11,000.
content:
Dengue fever is a common problem in Bagmati Province, Nepal.

Over 11,000 cases have been confirmed in the past 9 months, with Dhading having the most cases and Rasuwa having the least.

title: caste-discrimination-against-dalits-is-systemic-and-widespread-amnesty-international-report
content:
**Dalit Boy's Death Uncovered**

In 2016, Ajit Mijar, a Dalit boy, was found dead in suspicious circumstances. His father suspected murder and filed a report. A court acquitted the accused, but his father appealed. The High Court upheld the acquittal, and the Attorney General's Office decided not to appeal further.

**Caste-Based Discrimination in Nepal**

Amnesty International released a report highlighting caste-based discrimination in Nepal. Many Dalits are victims of violence and discrimination, but justice is often not served. Victims face obstacles in filing complaints and lack evidence.

**Systemic Impunity**

Despite laws against caste-based discrimination, impunity is widespread. Police discourage Dalits from filing complaints or beat them. The statute of limitations is inadequate, and there is a lack of Dalit representation in the justice system.

**Call for Action**

Amnesty International urges the Nepali authorities to create a plan to address caste-based violence and discrimination. This includes protecting Dalit women and girls, providing access to justice and reparations for survivors, and holding perpetrators accountable.
summary: On July 14, 2016, Ajit Mijar, 18, was found dead in Dhading in suspicious circumstances. The boy belonging to the Dalit community was in a relationship with a girl from the so-called ‘upper caste’, which her family opposed.The police recorded his death as suicide and his corpse declared as unidentified as he belonged to Kavrepalanchok, a different district. The body was quickly buried by the authorities without informing the family.Suspecting foul play, Hari Bhakta, Ajit's father, filed the first information report with the Area Police Office, Gajuri of Dhading on July 17, 2016, claiming the case to be murder. He named three relatives of the girl as suspects. The police, after investigating the incident, lodged a case in the district court. In June 2018, the Dhading District Court acquitted all three accused. The decision was challenged in a higher court. However, the Patan High Court in April 2022 upheld the lower court’s verdict to acquit the accused. After instructions from the High Court Public Prosecutor's Office, the Office of the Attorney General decided not to appeal the judgement. Unsatisfied with the decision, Ajit's father moved the Supreme Court challenging the decisions of the subordinate courts. Ajit's corpse is lying in a morgue in Tribhuvan University Teaching Hospital as his family is unwilling to perform the funeral rites until justice is served.“In Nepal, where caste-based discrimination is systemic and widespread, several Dalits like Mijar even lose lives due to the criminal practice,” read a research report by Amnesty International unveiled on Friday. “Yet justice is not served.”The report “No One Cares: Descent-Based Discrimination against Dalits” documents the experience of systemic caste-based discrimination in Nepal and the challenges they face in accessing justice.The report based on focus group discussions with 52 individuals from different sectors and one-on-one meetings with 21 representing Dalit communities from Madhesh, Lumbini and Karnali provinces says that the victims are discouraged to register complaints. And even when cases are lodged, there is no assurance of justice owing to the loopholes in the existing law, as per the report.It claims that at the time of registering a first information report (FIR), the Dalit victims are required to produce evidence of untouchability practice or the discrimination they faced. In some incidents, the victims are beaten by the police to deter them from filing the cases, states the report.As per the records at the Attorney General’s Office, as many as 52 cases relating to caste-based discrimination were filed in the district courts. Of them, 15 ended in conviction while 12 resulted in acquittal. Similarly, among 42 cases filed in the high courts, only 10 resulted in conviction.If the claim of Durga Sob, a Dalit rights activist, is anything to go by, less than five percent of cases of caste-based discrimination reach the police.The reports claim that untouchability has become a norm even if untouchability and caste-based discrimination have been prohibited and criminalised by law."Untouchability is an everyday affair in Nepal and the culture of impunity is deeply rooted in the society," said Monica Vincent, a lead researcher of the report. "The role of the police has been seen as a barrier in accessing justice."Officials at the Amnesty International say there are constitutional as well as legal instruments in place against the caste-based discrimination. However, they have not been rightly implemented.“The authorities in Nepal are not doing enough to counteract the culture of impunity for human rights violations related to descent-based discrimination in Nepal,” said Fernanda Doz Costa, Amnesty International’s director for gender and racial justice programme.“Efforts made by the authorities are still inadequate and insufficient, and they seem to exist only on paper but do not translate into real changes in the lives and the human rights of Dalits, Dalit women and girls in particular.”The organisation pointed out that impunity is rampant for several reasons, including inadequate statute of limitations provisioned in existing laws, lack of representation of Dalits in the justice system and institutional discrimination in the police and lack of effective oversight mechanisms and accountability.“Dalits do not trust the police and the justice system in general, and the limited government level data and statistics available [only 30-43 cases per year registered under the Caste-based Discrimination and Untouchability, (Offence and Punishment) Act] confirm their distrust is well-founded, including for Dalit women confronting caste-based violence,” reads the report.“The inactions or limited actions of Nepali authorities, including failing to hold public officers accountable and closing the trust deficits are reinforcing this culture of impunity and are sending a message to society that caste- and gender-based discrimination and violence are acceptable and natural.”Amnesty International said the Nepali authorities must create a holistic plan for a truly transformative response to uproot the caste- and gender-based violence and discrimination based on human rights obligations and with an intersectional lens.There is an urgent need to take special measures to improve the situation of Dalit women and girls due to the inter-generational history of oppression and entrenched culture of caste bias, patriarchy and discrimination, it said.“Nepal must fulfil its obligation to provide effective, timely and meaningful access to justice and reparations for survivors. It must move away from merely paying lip service to the ideals of achieving equality for all but take a concrete human-rights-centric approach to relegating descent-based discrimination to the dustbins of history,” said Costa.

title: Stress among students due to strict school rules has increased the demand for counseling services.
content:
**Mental Health in Schools**

Kenisha Thapa faced two years of stress at her new school, where strict rules and a lack of empathy from teachers caused her distress.

Schools play a crucial role in promoting students' mental health, especially during adolescence when youth are vulnerable. School counselors provide support and guidance, from academic issues to emotional concerns.

Research shows that many students face anxiety and depression. School counseling can create a healthy school environment by providing a safe space to talk, addressing issues privately, and involving parents and teachers in students' well-being.

School counselors can also identify and refer students with severe mental health problems to specialists.

Despite awareness among teachers about students' mental health, many lack understanding and need training to better support students.

Counseling can also address issues related to family background and economic status, which can impact academic performance.

Accessible school counseling is important, especially for students from underprivileged backgrounds. Government and community schools should prioritize providing these services.

Research indicates positive outcomes from school counseling, including improved academic performance and student well-being. Creating a school environment where students feel heard and supported is essential for their mental and educational growth.
summary: A student's mental anguish at a school with strict rules and lack of counseling reveals the importance of school counseling in promoting mental well-being, particularly during adolescence, where research shows a higher prevalence of anxiety and depression.

title: cruellest-crime
content:
**Nepal Children's Organization Land Scam**

The police have issued arrest warrants for 20 people involved in an illegal land deal. The deal involved the Nepal Children's Organization and the Brihaspati Vidya Sadan school. The land was illegally leased to the school for a low rent and the school then sub-leased it to another school for a higher rent.

The police investigation found that the land was worth much more than the amount it was leased for and that the money was not used to benefit the children's organization. The people who signed the lease deal and the owners of the school are facing arrest.

This scam is a reminder of other major land grab scams in Nepal, such as the Lalita Niwas and Bansbari Chhala Jutta cases. The government is working to get these properties back and prevent future illegal land grabs.
summary: Arrest warrants issued against 20 accused in Nepal Children's Organization land lease scam, including former officials and beneficiaries.

title:
**PhD Journey: Challenges and Triumphs**

Academics face challenges like stress, isolation, and imposter syndrome during their PhD studies. They also experience triumphs, such as breakthroughs, conference presentations, and publication. These challenges and triumphs are like a saga, with ups and downs that lead to personal growth and professional success.
content:
**PhD Options at Nepal's Tribhuvan University**

Previously, PhD students at Tribhuvan University only had the "PhD by dissertation" option. Now, they can also choose the "PhD by coursework" route.

**PhD by Coursework**

**Pros:**

* Exposes students to different aspects of their field.
* Prepares them for research and teaching.

**Cons:**

* At Tribhuvan University, the execution of the program has some challenges:
    * Departments lack trained faculty to teach doctoral courses.
    * Political interference in hiring makes it difficult to recruit qualified faculty.
    * Faculty teams often lack collaboration and cooperation.

**Need for Improvements**

To address these issues, the university needs to:

* Improve faculty recruitment processes.
* Encourage teamwork among faculty members.
* Ensure that departments have enough staff to run the program effectively.
summary: Tribhuvan University's shift to a "PhD by coursework" route for Humanities and Social Sciences faces challenges in execution due to insufficient disciplinary faculty, centralized control, and political interference in recruitment.

title: Due to climbers leaving behind trash and discarded gear, Mount Everest has become a high-altitude garbage dump. This pollution poses risks to the environment and human health.

title: karki-s-excesses-in-koshi
content:
Kedar Karki, the Chief Minister of Koshi Province, has lost support from his coalition partners and has been asked to form a new government. Karki has been holding on to power since April despite being in the minority.

Karki's rise to power was supported by the rival party, the CPN-UML, which caused internal conflicts within his own party and led to the downfall of the Congress-Maoist coalition government. Despite losing support from the UML, Karki has refused to resign or call for a floor test.

summary: Kathmandu Metropolitan City is providing vocational training to 1,500 youths, with plans to select 1,100 more for a second phase, aiming to enhance skills, provide basic knowledge, and facilitate job opportunities.

content: The Supreme Court has stopped the government of Gandaki Province in Nepal from making any important decisions. The government can only do everyday tasks. title: Investigation reveals that Nepal's Home Minister Lamichhane is involved in a cooperative financial fraud case in Pokhara, Nepal.
content:
**Deputy Prime Minister Accused of Embezzling Cooperative Funds**

Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane is accused of taking a loan of Rs 10 million from a Pokhara cooperative using false documents. The cooperative has filed a complaint against him and 18 others for embezzling Rs 1.35 billion in deposits.

**Loan Documents Found**

An investigation found a loan application form signed by Lamichhane. The cooperative approved a loan of Rs 10 million based on this form.

**Lamichhane Denies Involvement**

Despite the evidence, Lamichhane claims he did not receive any loans from cooperatives. However, the Attorney General's Office has recently cleared him of any cases in this matter.

**Victims Demand Justice**

Depositors have filed additional complaints and protested against the government's handling of the case. They allege that police tried to protect the accused and hide the investigation report.
summary: Home Minister Lamichhane faces accusations of embezzling millions from a Pokhara cooperative, based on probe findings and a report alleging suspicious loans, despite his denial and an OAG letter stating no cases against him.

title: Congress has been unable to reach an agreement on a budget, leading to a shutdown of the government.
content: The House of Representatives meeting was adjourned due to protests from Nepali Congress lawmakers. They demanded an investigation into Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane's involvement in alleged cooperative frauds. Despite the Speaker's attempts to proceed, the lawmakers blocked the meeting and adjourned it until Tuesday. The Congress has been demanding a parliamentary probe into Lamichhane's involvement in the scams, but the ruling parties' proposal for a broader inquiry was rejected. Before the national budget presentation, both Houses must approve the government's policies and programs, which are scheduled to be presented by the President on Tuesday.
summary: Nepali Congress lawmakers obstruct the first budget session of the House of Representatives, demanding a parliamentary probe into Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane; the meeting is adjourned until Tuesday.

title: India's Supreme Court has granted permission for opposition leader Arvind Kejriwal to participate in upcoming elections.
content: Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal, arrested in a corruption case, has been temporarily released on bail by India's top court. This allows him to campaign in the ongoing elections. The case involves allegations of corruption in Delhi's liquor policy. Kejriwal's party denies the allegations, while the government says its investigation agencies are independent. Voting began on April 19 and will continue until June 1, with counting set for June 4.

title: The Supreme Court has denied an urgent request to stop the Koshi Chief Minister from working while he faces corruption charges.
content: The Supreme Court declined to issue an immediate order regarding the appointment of Hikmat Karki as Chief Minister of Koshi. Instead, the court ordered the Province Head to provide reasons for the appointment within 10 days. The final hearing is set for May 22nd.

title: Nepal will use drones to remove garbage from Mount Everest. This will help keep the mountain clean and protected.
content:
**Drones to Remove Garbage from Mount Everest**

* Drones are being tested to help remove garbage from Mount Everest.
* If successful, drones could replace Sherpa guides who currently carry heavy loads through a dangerous area.
* Drones can carry up to 30 kg and fly up to 6,500 meters.
* Drones could reduce the risk of avalanches for guides.
* The use of drones could impact the livelihood of high-altitude support staff.

title:
**Adoption in Nepal**

Adopting a child in Nepal is challenging due to a lack of clear laws and regulations. This makes the process uncertain and complicated for prospective adoptive parents.
content:
Anistha, a woman in Nepal, struggled to have a baby. After losing two children, she gave up hope but then found an abandoned baby and raised him as her own.

Legal adoption in Nepal is complex, with requirements for couples and criteria for children. While the law prioritizes children's well-being, it lacks clear regulations, which can lead to problems.

There is no committee to match children with parents, and potential parents often find children on their own, which can put children at risk.

The law also forbids adoption by same-sex couples, limiting their ability to have children.

Intercountry adoptions, once popular, have been banned due to concerns about trafficking and abuse.
summary: Anistha Shrestha, after failed pregnancies and adoption attempts, stumbled upon an abandoned baby boy to raise as her own, highlighting the complexities and challenges of adoption in Nepal, including legal hurdles, lack of regulation, safety concerns, and societal barriers for queer communities.

Increased tensions in the Middle East after Iran's attack on Israel could hurt Nepal's economy.

* Nepal relies heavily on money sent home by workers abroad (remittances), especially from the Middle East.
* If workers in the Middle East lose their jobs or have to come home, remittances will decline.
* This would hurt Nepal's economy, which depends on remittances for a large part of its income.

**Other Impacts:**

* Oil prices are rising, which will increase inflation in Nepal.
* Shipping costs could go up, making it more expensive to import goods.
* Tourist arrivals may decline if travel advisories are issued.
* Foreign aid and investment may decrease.

**What Can Nepal Do?**

* Prepare strategies to handle the potential shock of a decline in remittances.
* Consider the impacts on the economy of rising oil prices, shipping costs, and inflation.
* Monitor the situation closely and adjust economic policies accordingly.
summary: Escalating tensions in the Middle East, triggered by Iran's missile attack on Israel, threaten to destabilize Nepal's economy, heavily reliant on remittances, potentially leading to labor market disruptions, rising inflation, and a decline in foreign currency reserves.

title: Political parties change their views based on what suits them best, instead of what is best for the country.
content:
**Summary:**

The two largest political parties in Nepal, the Nepali Congress and the Communist Party of Nepal-Unified Marxist-Leninist (CPN-UML), have opposing views on forming investigation committees.

**CPN-UML's Position:**

Last year, the CPN-UML (then in opposition) demanded a judicial commission to investigate gold smuggling allegations against leaders of the Nepali Congress and CPN (Maoist Centre). Now, they oppose the Nepali Congress's demand for a parliamentary investigation into Home Minister Rabi Lamichhane's alleged embezzlement of cooperative funds.

**Nepali Congress's Position:**

The Nepali Congress (now in opposition) supported the CPN-UML's demand for a judicial commission on gold smuggling but now wants a parliamentary probe into Lamichhane's case. They argue that powerful individuals have undermined the investigation.

**Differences in Views:**

The differing views stem from each party's position in the government:

* When in opposition, the CPN-UML demanded a judicial commission due to doubts about the state's ability to prosecute ruling party leaders.
* Now, the Nepali Congress supports a parliamentary probe, claiming the state apparatus is biased in favor of Lamichhane.

**Political Experts' Perspective:**

Political experts criticize the parties' double standards and believe that both parliamentary and judicial committees should be used sparingly. They argue that political parties should trust the state machinery rather than resorting to extra measures.
summary: The Nepali Congress and the CPN-UML have reversed their stances on parliamentary investigation committees, with the former now demanding an investigation into Home Minister Rabi Lamichhane while the latter opposes it, citing the successful judicial commission in the gold smuggling case previously demanded by the UML.

title: The government plans to check pregnant women for mental health issues.
content:
**Mental Health Screening for Pregnant Women**

Nepal plans to start screening pregnant women for mental health problems. This is because many women dying during childbirth have mental health issues. The screening will be offered at Thapathali Maternity Hospital and then rolled out to other areas.

Nepal wants to reduce the number of women dying during childbirth. In the past, the rate was reduced, but it has gone up again. Postpartum bleeding and high blood pressure during pregnancy are the main causes of deaths during pregnancy.

However, self-harm (suicide) is also a significant cause of deaths during pregnancy. To address this, Nepal is working to improve the quality of health services and the ability to refer women to hospitals when needed. Also, ambulances will be made available for emergency calls.

Nepal has free institutional delivery and travel allowances for women to use these services. The government is also giving out a medication to treat bleeding after childbirth.
summary: Nepal's Health Ministry plans to screen pregnant women for mental health issues to curb alarmingly high maternal deaths caused by suicide, with the aim of meeting the UN's Sustainable Development Goal of reducing maternal mortality to 75 per 100,000 births by 2030.

title: Doctors and health workers receive specialized training to screen and prevent non-communicable diseases (NCDs).
content:
**Trained Health Workers Screen for Non-Communicable Diseases in Kathmandu**

Over 50 health workers have been trained to screen for major non-communicable diseases (NCDs) like high blood pressure, diabetes, and heart disease. Patients seeking care at local health facilities will be screened, allowing for timely diagnosis and treatment.

NCDs are now the leading cause of death in Nepal, accounting for 71% of deaths. Medicines for some NCDs are provided free of cost at state-run health facilities.

The training aims to reduce the burden of NCDs by improving detection and care. Health workers will prescribe medicines, counsel patients, and refer them to specialists if necessary.
summary: Kathmandu health workers received training to screen patients for non-communicable diseases, including high blood pressure, heart disease, cancer, and diabetes.

- DDA admits testing too few samples, leading to concerns about the quality of medicines being used by patients.
- Experts warn that substandard medicines can harm health.
- DDA faces challenges due to understaffing and insufficient laboratory capacity.
- Delays in testing mean that substandard drugs may be sold before results are known.
- DDA struggles to monitor the large number of pharmacies with only a limited number of drug inspectors.
summary: Despite collecting around 1,000 medicine samples annually, the Department of Drug Administration, Nepal's drug regulatory body, has tested less than 2% of registered drugs, resulting in delays in identifying substandard medicines, which could adversely affect patient health.

* They contain Vitamins B1, B6, C, and minerals like potassium and copper.
* They're energy-dense and free of fat and cholesterol.

Potatoes can improve health by:

* Supporting heart, muscle, and nervous system health with potassium.
* Providing fiber for digestive health.
* Boosting immunity with Vitamin A.

Nepal produces millions of tons of potatoes annually. Red and white potatoes are common, but purple potatoes are growing in popularity.

* **Red Potatoes:** Popular and nutrient-rich.
* **Dark Potatoes:** Packed with antioxidants.
* **Sweet Potatoes:** Good source of Vitamin A.
* **Purple Potatoes:** Rich in antioxidants to prevent heart disease and cancer.

* Popular snacks, but high in calories and low in nutrients.
* Frying reduces nutrient content.

**Note for Diabetics:**

* Limit potato intake due to high carbohydrate content.
summary: Potatoes are a widely consumed staple food in Nepal, providing essential nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and fiber, despite being sometimes used as a derogatory term; despite its nutritional value, excessive consumption of potato chips and french fries can lead to weight gain.

summary: Piano Piano South, an Italian restaurant in Sanepa, offers a delightful culinary journey with an antipasti selection, hearty main courses, delectable desserts, and a well-curated wine list, providing a tranquil escape from the city's hustle and bustle with its indoor and outdoor seating options.

title:
**7 Must-Visit Places in Nepal for 2024:**

1. Kathmandu: Vibrant cultural hub with ancient temples and monuments
2. Pokhara: Serene lake city with stunning mountain views
3. Chitwan National Park: Home to endangered rhinos and tigers
4. Everest Base Camp Trek: Epic hike offering breathtaking Himalayan panoramas
5. Lumbini: Birthplace of Buddha, pilgrimage site
6. Nagarkot: Hill station with panoramic mountain views
7. Bandipur: Charming medieval town with traditional Newari architecture
content:
**Mundhum Trek**

* Cultural walk through indigenous villages in eastern Nepal.
* Highlights Kirati culture and panoramic views of Mount Everest.
* Requires tents and advance planning.

**Janaki Mandir**

* Largest temple in Nepal, with 60 rooms.
* Honors Janaki (Sita) and her marriage to Ram.
* Celebrated during Vivaha Panchami (December).

**Kuri Village**

* Snow-capped destination near Kathmandu.
* Offers stunning Himalayan views.
* Best visited during winter for snow activities.

**Annapurna Base Camp**

* Short and affordable trek to the foothills of Annapurna.
* Showcases Nepali culture, villages, and wildlife.
* Ideal for trekking in autumn and spring.

**Bardiya National Park**

* Home to the Royal Bengal Tiger.
* Offers jungle safaris and opportunities for wildlife viewing.
* Best visited during the dry season (September to May).

**Khaptad National Park**

* Offbeat and pristine protected area in western Nepal.
* Ideal for trekking in spring and autumn.
* Bring your own camping gear and supplies.
summary: Nepal boasts cultural trails like Mundhum Trek featuring stunning views, historic sites like Janaki and Ram Mandir, picturesque landscapes of Kuri Village, breathtaking Annapurna Base Camp, wildlife sanctuaries in Bardiya and Khaptad National Parks, and the remote and serene Limi Valley.

title: Phidim is a town in Nepal that is experiencing changes. While some people hold on to traditional ways, others embrace new technologies and ideas. This mix of old and new is shaping the town's identity.
content:
The author returned to his hometown, Phidim, after a long time. He found that it had changed a lot. New buildings and paved roads had replaced old houses and dirt roads. Despite the transformation, the author felt a sense of nostalgia for the Phidim of his memories.

The author concluded that Phidim is in a state of transition, trading its rustic charm for the hallmarks of urbanization. However, he also realized that this is a common experience, as people leave their hometowns in search of better opportunities. Phidim remains etched in the author's heart, a testament to the intricate dance between memory and evolution.
summary: Returning to his hometown of Phidim, the author discovers remarkable transformation, from old houses to modern buildings, but also notes the decline of the town due to a lack of opportunity, resulting in an exodus of its people.

title: Architecture and art merge seamlessly
content: Lucknow, known as the "smiling city," is a vibrant place with historic landmarks like Bara Imambara. Built in 1784 to help people during a famine, this complex has grand gates, an elegant mosque, and a massive hall called Asafi Hall. The hall's vaulted roof stands without any pillars and is a marvel of engineering. Inside the Imambara is a confusing maze called Bhool Bhulaiyaa, where sound echoes through the corridors. The complex also has an underground royal stepwell with intricate carvings and a hidden "CCTV" system using water reflections.
summary: Bara Imambara, a historic building in Lucknow, known for its grand architecture, labyrinthine Bhool Bhulaiyaa, and Shahi Baoli with a CCTV-like well design.

title: Of-Treks-and-Trails offers a variety of guided trekking and hiking adventures in different countries. The company provides professional guidance, local support, and tailored itineraries to ensure a safe and unforgettable experience.
content:
**Climbing Mountains:**

* Climbing requires facing cold, hunger, and physical challenges.
* Guides help trekkers navigate rocky paths and bridges.
* Nepal's economy relies on climbing and trekking guides.

**Tips for Beginners:**

* **Stay Positive:** Belief in yourself can help you succeed.
* **Prepare Physically:** Train, walk, and stretch to build strength and endurance.
* **Pack Smart:** Choose lightweight, warm clothing. Bring essentials like down jackets, gloves, and a safety knife.

**Managing Challenges:**

* **Altitude Sickness:** Rest and wait for symptoms to subside.
* **Injuries:** Carry painkillers and seek medical help if needed.
* **Period Management:** Bring supplies and handle cramps as best you can.
* **Female Trekkers:** Face stereotypes and underestimation, but stay strong.

**Becoming a Trekking Guide:**

* Join a trekking association and enroll in a guide course.
* Learn skills like map reading, guiding techniques, and safety measures.
* Consider a bachelor's program in mountaineering for a comprehensive education.
summary: Experienced guides Luckme Syangden and Manu Rai share tips and highlight the challenges faced by trekkers while navigating the treacherous heights of Everest, Annapurna, and Manaslu, emphasizing the importance of maintaining a positive mindset, physical preparation, and effective communication.

title:

- **Cultural Immersion:** Experience the vibrant Nepali culture through visits to temples, meeting locals, and trying traditional dishes.

content:

Five women founded Duluwa Outdoors to encourage women to travel independently. Solo travel is safe in Nepal, where many women have traveled alone for generations.

**Tips for Solo Travel:**

* Plan ahead: research transportation, lodging, and activities.
* Dress for the location and consider potential risks.
* Budget carefully and keep an emergency fund.

**Safety Tips:**

* Arrive at settlements before dark and stay overnight if possible.
* Be aware of wildlife and natural disasters.
* Consider wilderness first aid training.
* Trust your instincts and inform someone of your whereabouts.
summary: 5 female travelers launched Duluwa Outdoors in 2021 to empower women in Nepal to travel solo and connect through social media, sharing safety tips and travel destinations for solo travelers.

title: Nepal defeated West Indies A by 2 wickets in the final match of the one-day series. Nepal won the series 2-3.
content:

Despite losing the series 3-2, Nepal won the fifth match by six wickets thanks to:

* Impressive bowling by Sagar Dhakal and Sompal Kami.

content:
**Nepal Loses to West Indies A in T20 Series**

In the fourth T20 match, Nepal lost to West Indies A by 28 runs. Nepal needs to score 210 runs, but could only score 181.

Rohit Paudel was the only Nepali player in good form, scoring 82 runs. Other batsmen like Aasif Sheikh, Kushal Bhurtel, and Kushal Malla struggled.

content:
Nepal's T20 World Cup squad features experienced players from the recent Asian Cup.

Despite a recent loss, the team retains most of the core. Captain Rohit Paudel leads the squad, aiming to address batting struggles.

title: Israel conducted airstrikes in eastern Rafah, Gaza, after ceasefire talks ended without an agreement.
content:
**Israeli Bombardment in Rafah**

Israel attacked areas in Rafah, killing several people, including women and children. Israel claims Hamas militants are hiding there and plans to continue the operation.

**US Warning**

US President Biden warned Israel against a full-scale invasion of Rafah, threatening to withhold weapons. Israel dismissed the threat and said it will proceed with its plans.

**Negotiations End**

Talks between Hamas, Israel, and mediators in Cairo have ended without reaching a ceasefire deal.

**Gaza Crisis**

Israeli strikes have killed thousands of Palestinians, injured many, and forced hundreds of thousands to flee their homes. The closure of the Rafah border with Egypt has cut off a vital aid route and halted the evacuation of wounded and sick people.

**Medical Crisis**

Gaza's medical system is collapsing due to lack of supplies and access. Hospitals are unable to operate, and many essential services have been disrupted.
summary: Israeli forces bombarded areas of Rafah on Thursday, Palestinian residents said, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu dismissed US President Joe Biden’s threat to withhold weapons from Israel if it assaults the southern Gaza city.A senior Israeli official said late on Thursday that the latest round of indirect negotiations in Cairo to halt hostilities in Gaza had ended and Israel would proceed with its operation in Rafah and other parts of the Gaza Strip as planned.Israel has submitted to mediators its reservations about a Hamas proposal for a hostage release deal, the official said.“If we must, we shall fight with our fingernails,” Netanyahu said in a video statement. “But we have much more than our fingernails.”In Gaza, Palestinian militant groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad said their fighters fired anti-tank rockets and mortars at Israeli tanks massed on the eastern outskirts of the city.Residents and medics in Rafah, the biggest urban area in Gaza not yet overrun by Israeli ground forces, said an Israeli attack near a mosque killed at least three people and wounded others in the eastern Brazil neighbourhood.Video footage from the scene showed the minaret lying in the rubble and two bodies wrapped in blankets.An Israeli air strike on two houses in the Sabra neighbourhood of Rafah killed at least 12 people including women and children.Among the dead was a senior commander of the militant Al-Mujahedeen Brigades, and his family, and the family of another group leader, medics, relatives and the group said.Israel says Hamas militants are hiding in Rafah, where the population has been swelled by hundreds of thousands of Gazans seeking refuge from the bombardments that have reduced most of the coastal enclave to ruins.In the United States, the White House repeated its hope that Israel would not launch a full operation in Rafah, saying it did not believe that would advance Israel’s aim of defeating Hamas.“Smashing into Rafah, in [President Biden’s] view, will not advance that objective,” spokesperson John Kirby said.Kirby said Hamas had been pressured significantly by Israel and there were better options to hunt down what remains of the group’s leadership than an operation with significant risk to civilians.Israel’s assault on Gaza has killed nearly 35,000 Palestinians and wounded nearly 80,000, most of them civilians, the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza said.It launched its offensive in response to a cross-border attack by Hamas militants on Israel on October 7 in which they killed about 1,200 people and abducted 252. Some 128 hostages remain in Gaza and 36 have been declared dead, according to the latest Israeli figures.Biden on Wednesday issued his starkest warning yet against a full ground invasion in Rafah, telling CNN that: “I made it clear that if they go into Rafah...I’m not supplying the weapons.”Israel’s ambassador to the United States said the decision to withhold weapons from Israel over Rafah sends the “wrong message” to Hamas and the country’s foes.“It puts us in a corner because we have to deal with Rafah one way or the other,” Ambassador Michael Herzog told a Carnegie Endowment for International Peace webinar.The Israeli military has the munitions it requires for operations in Rafah and other planned operations, chief armed forces spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said.Israeli armed forces have already killed 50 Palestinian gunmen in east Rafah and uncovered several tunnels, Hagari said. Hamas had no immediate comment.TALKS ENDIn Cairo, delegations from Hamas, Israel, the US, Egypt and Qatar had been meeting since Tuesday. The talks in Egypt’s capital made some headway but no deal was reached, according to two Egyptian security sources.Izzat El-Risheq, a member of Hamas’ political office in Qatar, said the Hamas delegation had left Cairo, having reaffirmed its approval of the mediators’ ceasefire proposal. The plan entails the release of Israeli hostages held captive in Gaza and a number of Palestinians jailed by Israel.Hamas blames Israel for the lack of agreement, and its Al-Aqsa TV’s Telegram account said the group would not make any concessions beyond those in the proposal it had accepted.Israel has said it is open to a truce, but has rejected demands for an end to the war.US State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said Washington continued to engage with Israel on amendments to a ceasefire proposal, adding work to finalise the text of an agreement was “incredibly difficult”.MEDICAL SECTOR COLLAPSINGIsraeli residents set fire twice to the perimeter of the headquarters of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees in East Jerusalem, causing extensive damage to the outdoor areas but no casualties, UNRWA chief Philippe Lazzarini wrote on X. There was no immediate comment from Israeli police.“Once again, the lives of UN staff were at a serious risk,” Lazzarini wrote, adding he had decided to close the compound until security is restored.On Tuesday, Israeli tanks seized the Gaza side of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt, cutting off a vital aid route and forcing 80,000 people to flee the city this week, according to the United Nations.Israel kept up tank and aerial strikes across Gaza and tanks advanced in the Zeitoun neighbourhood of Gaza City in the north, forcing hundreds of families to flee, residents said. The Israeli military said it was securing Zeitoun, starting with a series of intelligence-based aerial strikes on approximately 25 militant targets.Deir Al-Balah in central Gaza was packed with people who had fled Rafah in recent days. Palestinian medics said two people, including a woman, were killed when a drone fired a missile at a group of people there.The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has prevented the evacuation of the wounded and sick and the entry of medical supplies, food trucks and fuel needed to operate hospitals, the Gaza health ministry said on Thursday.The only kidney dialysis centre in the Rafah area had stopped operating due to the shelling.“The entire medical sector has collapsed,” said Ali Abu Khurma, a Jordanian surgeon volunteering at Al Aqsa hospital in Deir al-Balah.United Nations aid chief Martin Griffiths said that for three consecutive days, “nothing and no one has been allowed in or out of Gaza.”“It means no aid. Our supplies are stuck. Our teams are stuck. Civilians in Gaza are being starved and killed, and we are prevented from helping them. This is Gaza today, even after 7 months of horrors,” Griffiths posted on X.

title: Due to ongoing fighting near Rafah, the US has temporarily stopped some weapon supplies to Israel.
content:
**Hamas and Israel clash near Rafah.**

**USA stops weapons shipment to Israel amid concerns.**

**USA and Egypt push for ceasefire.**

**US official says Washington paused delivery of heavy bombs.**

**Israeli forces enter Rafah, cutting off aid.**
