summary: Hamas said it was battling Israeli troops on the outskirts of the Gaza Strip’s crowded southern city of Rafah on Wednesday after a US official said Washington had halted a shipment of powerful bombs that Israel could use in a full-scale assault.The United States, which is seeking to stave off an Israeli invasion of Rafah, said it believes a revised Hamas ceasefire proposal may lead to a breakthrough in an impasse in negotiations, with talks resuming in Cairo on Wednesday.A senior US official said President Joe Biden’s administration paused a shipment of weapons to Israel last week in an apparent response to the expected Rafah offensive. The White House and Pentagon declined to comment.The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Washington had carefully reviewed the delivery of weapons that might be used in Rafah, and as a result paused a shipment consisting of 1,800 2,000-lb bombs and 1,700 500-lb bombs.This would be the first such delay since the Biden administration offered its “ironclad” support to Israel after Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack. Washington is Israel’s closest ally and main weapons supplier.A senior Israeli official declined to confirm the report, asking not to be named: “If we have to fight with our fingernails, then we’ll do what we have to do,” the source said. A military spokesperson said any disagreements were resolved in private.Israeli forces seized the main border crossing between Gaza and Egypt in Rafah on Tuesday, cutting off a vital aid route.Residents and officials said Rafah’s city council building was hit by Israeli tank fire on Tuesday and caught fire.“The streets of the city echo with the cries of innocent lives lost, families torn apart, and homes reduced to rubble. We stand on the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe of unprecedented proportions,” Rafah’s mayor, Ahmed Al-Sofi, said in an appeal to the international community to intervene.The Israeli military said on Wednesday it had uncovered Hamas infrastructure in several locations in eastern Rafah and its troops were conducting targeted raids on the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing and airstrikes across the Gaza Strip.It has told civilians to go to an “expanded humanitarian zone” in al-Mawasi, some 20 km (12 miles) away.Armed groups of Hamas, Islamic Jihad and Fatah said in separate statements that gunfights continued in the central Gaza Strip, while residents of northern Gaza reported heavy Israeli tank shelling against eastern areas of Gaza City and districts.CEASEFIRE TALKSIn Cairo, all five delegations participating in talks on Tuesday - Hamas, Israel, the US, Egypt and Qatar - reacted positively to the resumption of negotiations, and meetings were expected to continue on Wednesday, two Egyptian sources said.CIA Director Bill Burns was to travel from Cairo to Israel on Wednesday to meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his Mossad counterpart, an Israeli government source said.Israel on Monday declared that a three-phase proposal approved by Hamas was unacceptable because terms had been watered down. White House spokesperson John Kirby said the new text presented by Hamas suggests the remaining gaps can “absolutely be closed.”The proposal included a first phase with a six-week ceasefire, an influx of aid to Gaza, the return of 33 Israeli hostages, alive or dead, and the release by Israel of 30 detained Palestinian children and women for each released Israeli hostage, according to several sources.Since a week-long ceasefire in November, the only pause so far, the two sides have been blocked by Hamas’ refusal to free more Israeli hostages without a promise of a permanent end to the conflict and Israel’s insistence on only a temporary halt.Israel’s offensive has killed 34,789 Palestinians, most of them civilians, the Gaza Health Ministry said.The war began when Hamas militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and abducting 252 others, of whom 128 remain hostage in Gaza and 36 have been declared dead, according to the latest Israeli figures.Al-Sofi, Rafah’s mayor, said 1.4 million people sheltering in the city had nowhere to go. Those in eastern neighbourhoods were being told to move to the coastal al-Mawasi area “which lacks the necessities of life”, he said.Around 200 patients from Rafah’s Abu Youssef al-Najjar Hospital, in an area designated by the Israeli army as a combat zone, were forced to evacuate to the west of the city after receiving calls warning them to leave, health officials said.Israel was reopening Kerem Shalom crossing on its border with the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, a statement from the Israeli agency in charge of it said, adding aid trucks routed through from Egypt were already undergoing security inspections there.Israel had closed Kerem Shalom crossing on Sunday after Palestinian shelling nearby killed four soldiers. The United Nations had warned the closure of both the Rafah and Kerem Shalom crossings had “choked off” the two main arteries for getting aid into Gaza, with stocks low inside the enclave.

title: unauthorised-translation-and-piracy-of-foreign-books-thrive-in-nepal
content:
**Unauthorized Book Translations in Nepal**

Many popular international books have unauthorized translations in Nepal, meaning they were translated without permission from the authors or publishers.

**Impacts**

* Authors lose royalties and creative control.
* Readers receive poor-quality translations.

**Major Authors Affected**

* Taslima Nasrin: All of her books have unauthorized Nepali translations.
* Steve Jobs: "Steve Jobs" by Walter Isaacson.
* Rich Dad Poor Dad: Three Nepali translations, all unauthorized.

**Contributing Factors**

* Lack of enforcement of copyright laws.
* Desire for easy money among publishers.

**Government Response**

* Copyright Act (2002) exists but is not strictly enforced.
* Plan to amend the Act to give the registrar's office more autonomy.

**Consequences**

* Harming Nepal's book publishing industry.
* Tarnished reputation in the global market.
* Lack of inspiration for authors to create works.

**Possible Solutions**

* Cooperation between government, publishers, and authors.
* Seizure of pirated books.
* Inclusion of digital piracy and international treaty rules in law.
summary: Unauthorized translations of popular international books by renowned authors, including Taslima Nasrin, Steve Jobs, Robert Kiyosaki, and Shiv Khera, have flooded Nepal's book market, harming authors and publishers while compromising translation quality.

title: Young people from an area where Maoist rebels operate are struggling to find opportunities in the United States.
content:
**Illegal Immigration to the United States**

Villages in eastern Nepal have been affected by a surge in illegal immigration to the United States. Many young people have paid large sums to human traffickers to get to the US, but many have been deported and lost everything they had.

Deported youths have faced hardships and lost an average of $6 million each. The village of Tak has been particularly hard hit, with over 40 million dollars lost by its residents.

Loans taken out for these journeys have left many in debt, forcing some families to flee their homes. The lack of legal remedies and political will has allowed this phenomenon to continue.

Nepalis continue to attempt to reach the US illegally, despite the risks involved. The lack of economic opportunities and the presence of human traffickers are contributing factors to this trend.

The number of deportees and the amounts lost remain largely unknown, highlighting the urgent need for more research and legal protections for victims.
summary: Bharat Budha, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality’s ward 10, knows that many youths from his village have made it to the United States via ‘tallo bato’—backdoor route—and that many are still on the way. He also knows that eight of them have been deported from the country and that they have lost a cumulative Rs45 million in the process. The deported youths say that they returned home empty-handed after facing unspeakable ordeals and lost Rs6 million each on average.The Tak village in Rukum East—a close-knit settlement of 425 houses—was considered the Maoists’ ‘base area’ during the insurgency. Village youths who reached the US through illegal routes and got deported have lost an estimated Rs40 million. The number of those who returned without completing the journey and the amount they lost remain unknown.To get to the US, the youths have taken loans at up to 36 percent interest per annum from their relatives and village landowners. In Tak village, at least one person each from half of the households has gone abroad, Budha said. “Youths started going to America about six-seven years ago,” he said. “If they could gather enough money, the whole village would try to go to the US.” Budha’s own son had reached the US illegally in 2017, spending Rs3.2 million.During the insurgency, outsize slogans of revolution would adorn the walls of houses in the village. Hoping for a better life, people from all walks of life helped out the Maoists. But now, village youths are paying the agents to illegally get to the US—a country that the Maoists used to call their ‘enemy’, an ‘imperialistic force’. This has cost the Tak village much and in multiple ways.Death of a dreamSome of the deported youths have chosen to flee the village altogether, burdened with debt and creditors’ pressure. At least five such families have already left, said a resident. The family of Ram Budha was one of them. On April 28, 2015, Ram, who had returned to Nepal after working in Malaysia for eight years, took the illegal route to the US. He travelled through arduous trails for months and finally arrived in the country. Upon reaching the country, he was detained and had to stay at the detention camp for 27 months. When his refugee application was rejected, he was deported to Nepal in mid-December 2019. He lost Rs4.5 million in the process. He now owes over Rs6 million to creditors. “After the creditors began to put pressure on me, I couldn’t live in the village peacefully,” said Ram, who currently runs a vegetable farm in Tarakeshwar, Kathmandu.While those who got to the US through illegal routes and fortunately got refugee status there narrate their stories with pride, those who have been deported or returned from half-way have tragic tales to tell.Nanda Kala Gharti, who lives in a small stone house on the upper flank of Tak village, spends her days in melancholy. Her husband, Dhanlal, had chosen to take the illegal route to the US, and Nanda Kala, a mother of four, is living with the repercussions of his decision. Dhanlal had got into the US after a six-month long arduous journey and was detained immediately. He had to spend four years in the detention camp, before he was deported to Nepal. He had already lost Rs6 million.Nanda Kala said they now have an insurmountable crisis in their hands. Pointing to her son, she exclaimed, “When will he grow up, go abroad and pay back the loans!”Dhanlal himself tried to go to Croatia once and spent 15 days in Kathmandu for the process. But after he was turned down, he returned home dejected. “Now we will submit the passport to another agent [for Dhanlal’s trip abroad],” Nanda Kala said. “There’s no point staying here.”Stories that echo each otherThe situation in Sisne Rural Municipality is similar to that of Putha Uttarganga. Here, one can hear plenty of stories of those who have tried to go to the US and those who are fighting refugee cases there. Krishna Regmi, chair of the rural municipality, personally knows seven people who have been deported from the US.Gangaram Khadka, a resident of Sisne-3, runs a bee and chicken farm. Like other young men in his village, Khadka had headed off to the US via an illegal route on 27 March, 2018. He had reached the US via the New Delhi-Moscow-Barcelona-Bogota-Panama-Costa Rica-Nicaragua-Honduras-Guatemala-Mexico route. When he finally arrived in the US, he was detained and had to spend 11 months in detention. He was deported on 15 March, 2019. He had handed over Rs3.2 millions to the agent and spent Rs2 million to fight the case to become a refugee. “It’s not possible for me to pay back the loan while working in Nepal,” he said. “I aim to pay back some interest and head off abroad again.”For six months after Khadka was deported, he had anxiety and headache, he said, adding the three people from his village who were deported like him are also struggling with their mental health.Tikaram Pun, a 40-year-old resident of Bohora village in Musikot-4, is also haunted by his past journey. In September 2017, he reached the US after crossing 17 countries with the help of organised human traffickers. Of the 41 people in his group, 31 were from Rukum East and Rukum West, he said. Pun, who was detained on arrival in the US, spent 24 months in a detention camp. His refugee application was also refused and so he was deported along with eight other Nepalis. “When I returned, I started having mental health problems. I still suffer from them,” he said. Pun is under pressure from creditors and relatives to pay back the Rs9.2 million loan he had taken for the task.Those who died on the wayA group of 10 Bangladeshis and seven Nepalis, including Rupak Bohora of Bafikot-3 in Rukum West, were on a mission to reach Costa Rica through Colombia, Caribbean Coast, Capuragana and Panama. But while they were crossing a sea, their boat capsized. As many as 12 died in the incident, including six Nepalis. Rupak’s wife, Geeta, learned about the incident only after six days, on 25 June, 2021.“I still don’t know what exactly happened,” said Geeta, who had been married off at age 19 and is now a mother of two daughters. The only thing she knows is that Rupak has died and she is now all alone. And that she has Rs5 million in loan taken for Rupak’s trip. She showed a picture of her husband on her phone to this scribe and said, “I only have memories.”Lack of political will and legal remediesThe concrete bridge over Chewang river is on the edge of Tak village. On the walls of the bridge are paintings of political theorists like Marx, Engels, Lenin, Stalin and Mao, and the iconic slogan, ‘Workers of the world, unite!’, below them. But the slogan appears to be at odds with life in the village. Given the phenomenon of illegal travels to the US through the help of organised human traffickers, the whole village appears to be emptying. Neither the local governments are concerned about the phenomenon nor are the political parties paying attention.Puniraj Gharti, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality, said though the trend is worrying, there’s nothing he can do. “How could we stop them from making the trip when they are struggling to make a living in the village?” he said.Krishna Regmi, chair of Sisne Rural Municipality, said that the vicious cycle of poverty started after marijuana farming was banned in the country. Then the Maoist insurgency added to the woe, forcing youths to migrate. The signing of the peace agreement in 2006 didn’t herald any change in the economy either and youths are struggling to get jobs. Organised human traffickers are cashing in on this sorry state of affairs, Regmi said. “Meter byajis [usurious lenders] are also promoting this phenomenon,” he added.The phenomenon is equally rife in Dang’s Tulsipur and Ghorahi. Ramesh Kumar Pandey, chair of Ghorai-15, says that even though many heading to the US are swindled, no complaints are filed at the ward office. “Only those who attempt to go to Saudi Arabia or Qatar file the complaints,” he said.One can infer from Pandey’s statements that the families of such illegal travellers don’t want to publicise the ordeals of their family members. On the one hand, agents threaten them to not publicise the issue; on the other, they fear they themselves would be punished by law.According to the Anti-Human Trafficking Bureau, as many as 178 Nepalis, including 174 men, have been deported from the US in the five fiscal years after 2018-19. Of them, the highest 49 are from Rukum while 37 are from Dang. The data doesn’t include those who returned after making it to the half-way or those who have been fighting the legal battle in the US for refugee status. But this data is enough to show that many such youths are from the ‘base areas’ of the Maoist insurgency.SSP Jeevan Shrestha, chief of the bureau, said that data on the number of such victims and the amounts they have spent is hard to collect since complaints are rarely filed with the police. “This is human trafficking but for a lack of law, we are still compelled to launch the cases as per Human Trafficking and Transportation (Control) Act 2074 BS,” Shrestha said. “The Act provides a maximum penalty of Rs250,000 for the offenders and 50 percent of that as compensation to the victims.” Without specific law, police also invoke the theft and organised crime act to punish the offenders, he added.On the one hand, police receive no complaints; on the other, the phenomenon sees no control.Bhaskar Gautam, a political scientist, says the rise in cases of human trafficking in the insurgency’s ‘base areas’ is due to the political system’s abject failure.While the Maoists raised issues related to livelihood, nationalism and a new kind of democracy to fuel their war machine, after the peace process, it is livelihoods that have been hit the hardest, Gautam said. “The traditional way of life and economy took a hit during the insurgency,” he said. “Developments after the peace process also failed to address that. What sprang up was organised human trafficking.”(Mahesh KC in Rukum East and Durgalal KC in Dang contributed to this report.)This report is prepared in collaboration with the Center for Investigative Journalism-Nepal.

title: no-private-hospital-bed-for-poor-patients
content:
**Gyanumaya BK's Story:**

Gyanumaya spent thousands on back pain treatment at a private hospital. She was not aware that hospitals are supposed to provide free care to those who cannot afford it.

**Health Facility Operation Standards:**

In 2020, the government made a rule that requires private hospitals to reserve 10% of their beds and provide free treatment to the poor.

**Hospitals Not Following Rules:**

Many private hospitals, including the one Gyanumaya went to, do not follow the rules. They claim to give discounts but do not show proof.

**Monitoring and Enforcement Problems:**

Government agencies responsible for enforcing the rules lack manpower and motivation. They do not regularly inspect hospitals or take action against those that violate the rules.

**Call for Action:**

Officials believe that legal action and more effective monitoring are needed to ensure that private hospitals adhere to the government's mandate and provide essential healthcare to those who need it most.
summary: A 69-year-old laborer in Pokhara, Nepal, is struggling to pay off medical bills after discovering that her hospital was not adhering to regulations requiring them to provide free treatment and 10% of beds to the needy.

title:
**Nepali Bureaucracy**

The Nepali bureaucracy is known for its:

* **Hierarchy:** Strict chain of command and levels of authority.
* **Formalism:** Emphasis on rules, procedures, and paperwork.
* **Centralization:** Power concentrated in central government.
* **Patronage:** Personal relationships and favors influence decision-making.
* **Corruption:** Bribery, embezzlement, and misuse of public funds are common.
* **Inefficiency:** Slow decision-making, delays, and bureaucratic hurdles.
* **Lack of transparency:** Limited public access to government information.
* **Political interference:** Government officials influence bureaucratic decisions.
content:
**Nepali Bureaucracy: Two Sides of Power**

There are two different views of the Nepali bureaucracy:

1. **All-Powerful:** Politicians see bureaucrats as too powerful, challenging their authority.

2. **Submissive:** News reports often show bureaucrats working closely with politicians for their own benefit.

**How Can Bureaucrats Be Both Powerful and Submissive?**

Bureaucrats have more options today than in the past due to a stronger bureaucratic system:

* **Resist:** They can stand up to politicians if they do things against the law.
* **Maintain Status Quo:** They can keep things the same to avoid conflict.
* **Collude:** They can work with politicians for personal gain.

**Strengthening of Bureaucracy**

After 1990, new laws protected bureaucrats from unfair treatment by politicians. This gave them more power.

**Trade Unions and Politicization**

Political movements after 1990 made bureaucrats more active in politics. Trade unions for civil servants gave them even more influence.

**Multiple Options**

The stronger bureaucracy now gives bureaucrats more choices when dealing with politicians:

* **Positives:** They can resist illegal decisions.
* **Negatives:** They can also support or oppose based on their political views, keep things the same to protect their jobs, or collude for personal benefit.

**Implications**

* Too much power in the bureaucracy can lead to problems.
* However, taking away their protections can make them too subservient.
* Reforms are needed to balance power between bureaucrats and politicians.
summary: Contradictory narratives depict Nepali bureaucracy as both all-powerful and subservient, empowered by post-monarchy safeguards and politicization while facing fluctuating options and challenges.

title:
Massification of Education refers to the rapid growth and expansion of educational opportunities, making education accessible to a larger proportion of the population. This process involves:

* Increasing enrollment rates
* Establishing more schools and universities
* Making education affordable and accessible to all
content:
**Mass Higher Education: A Post-WWII Phenomenon**

Since the 1970s, there has been a rapid increase in people attending college, known as "mass higher education." This is a new concept that started after World War II.

**Origins:**

* **UK:** Planned for a wider participation in higher education to achieve social equality.
* **USA:** Expanded HE to increase scientific knowledge and skills needed for the economy.

**Expansion:**

* Funded by governments, corporations, and international organizations.
* Argued to be necessary for economic growth and competitiveness.
* Led to a boom in universities and colleges.

**Consequences:**

* Lower admission standards to accommodate more students.
* Dilution of academic content and grade inflation.
* Declining quality of higher education and a shortage of graduates with original research abilities.

**Lifelong Learning:**

* Promoted by UNESCO as a concept to encourage continuous learning throughout life.

**Concerns:**

* Business interests and private profit have influenced the expansion of mass higher education.
* It has led to a decline in the overall quality of higher education and a lack of graduates with the skills needed by employers.
summary: Post-WWII, global mass higher education's rapid expansion, initially driven by social equality and scientific advancement, has shifted toward a private commodity focused on economic growth.

title: India's Prime Minister, Modi, is expected to run for a third term in the upcoming election. Many people are worried about this because they believe he will further divide the country and weaken its democratic institutions.
content:
**Summary**

**India's Massive Election**

* Largest election ever, with over 500 members of parliament to be elected.
* Prime Minister Modi expected to win a third term easily.
* Parties are less involved, as the election is seen as a vote for or against Modi.
* Election campaigns have been lackluster, with little excitement.
* Voter turnout is lower than usual.

**Modi's Performance**

* Mixed record, with both successes and failures.
* Economic growth, but also rising inequality.
* Failures in handling demonetization and the COVID-19 pandemic.
* Aggressive foreign policy, but limited results.
* Tense relations with South Asian neighbors.

**Modi's Political Tactics**

* Presents himself as the only credible leader.
* Uses his supporters as cheerleaders.
* Weakens opposition through raids and fake news.

**Modi's Ambitions**

* Seeks to consolidate his power as an autocrat.
* Likely to spend more on image-building and military expansion.
* Nepal may face challenges in dealing with a third-term Modi government.
summary: India's largest-ever election, expected to result in another term for Prime Minister Modi despite a lack of excitement, highlights the country's democratic struggles with strongman rule and economic disparities.

title:
**Toilets for All**

Toilets-for-All is a program that aims to provide accessible and clean toilets to those in need, especially in areas with limited sanitation facilities. This includes:

* Building and maintaining public toilets in urban and rural areas
* Offering toilets to schools, hospitals, and other institutions
* Promoting hygiene and sanitation practices
* Ensuring toilets are accessible to people with disabilities

The program aims to improve public health, reduce the spread of disease, and create more hygienic and dignified living conditions for communities.
content:
**Gender-Inclusive Toilets: A Necessity for Everyone**

Activists are calling for toilets that don't separate people based on gender. This is important for transgender and non-binary people who often face discrimination and discomfort in public toilets.

Nepal is promoting gender equality and safety by building gender-inclusive toilets. These toilets are safe and respectful for everyone, regardless of their gender identity.

Many countries have gender-inclusive toilets, but it's important to also educate people about gender diversity and disability. This will create a more welcoming and inclusive society for all.

Gender-inclusive toilets can also boost tourism by making queer individuals feel welcome and accepted.
summary: Gender-inclusive toilets break the gender binary, welcoming all individuals regardless of gender identity, and are essential for marginalized communities like transgender and non-binary individuals, as their absence forces them to conform to societal norms, marginalizes them, and creates safety concerns, especially in schools, despite international examples and Nepal's efforts to promote equality.

title: Unity is strength; division leads to weakness.
content: Political parties in Nepal are constantly splitting and merging. This is mainly due to conflicts over power, not ideology. The recent split in the Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal is believed to have been caused by efforts to form an alternative coalition. Such splits weaken political movements and make people lose trust in parties. This also hurts the idea of a diverse and inclusive society.
summary: Political parties in Nepal, driven by power struggles, have once again engineered a split in a junior coalition partner, hindering the stability of the ruling coalition.

The main opposition party, the Nepali Congress, is demanding a probe into Home Minister Lamichhane's involvement. However, the Congress fears that the probe will be used to shield Lamichhane. Dahal has assured that the probe will be fair, but the Congress remains skeptical. The meeting point for both parties is that the embezzlement of cooperative funds needs to be addressed. summary: Prime Minister Dahal plans to address co-operative embezzlement concerns, including allegations against Home Minister Lamichhane, through a parliamentary probe, despite Congress skepticism and a call for a functional parliament during the budget session.

title:

Padam Giri, a renowned conservationist, highlights the importance of protecting the Himalayan ecosystem.

content:
**Budget session begins without resolving differences over probe committee**

Despite the upcoming budget session starting on Friday, the government and opposition parties remain at odds over forming a parliamentary committee to investigate fraud allegations against Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane.

The government argues that a broader investigation of the cooperative sector is necessary, rather than focusing on a single case. The opposition, however, insists on a committee specifically targeting Lamichhane.

Several bills await approval in parliament, including a bill to amend the Transitional Justice Act. Despite efforts to expedite bill endorsements, the parliament has been unproductive in this regard. The government is working to prioritize and consult widely in the drafting process.

summary: Nepal's federal parliament budget session commences without resolving the dispute over forming a committee to investigate fraud allegations against Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane, leading to uncertainty over the session's productivity.

title: Expect difficulties in the coming two months due to ongoing fires.
content:
**Fire Incidents in Nepal**

* 110 houses destroyed in Mahottari last week
* Several settlements burned in Gulmi, Rupandehi, and Arghakhanchi earlier
* 9 people have died in fires since April 13
* Fires caused by low rainfall, high temperatures, and wind gusts
* Accumulated forest litter and stubble burning have intensified blazes
* Inadequate resources, equipment, and trained personnel hinder firefighting efforts

**Government Response**

* Convening meetings and alerting authorities
* Training community forest group members to fight fires
* Introducing portable fire pumps, which are effective in difficult terrains
* Adopting advanced systems like helicopter firefighting
* Empowering local governments to lead the response
* Provinces assessing risks and assisting local governments
summary: Fire incidents have surged in Nepal due to lack of rainfall, soaring temperatures, winds, and inadequate forest fire management, resulting in loss of lives and property, prompting the government to implement measures such as training and equipping firefighters and introducing portable fire pumps.

content:
**Nepal Investment Summit**

Nepal is holding an investment summit to attract foreign investors. The government has learned from past summits and is taking steps to make it easier for investors to invest in Nepal.

**Attracting Investors**

Nepal is inviting successful investors to share their experiences and presenting the success stories of those who have invested in Nepal. The government has also made changes to laws to remove obstacles to foreign investment.

**Improving Investment Climate**

The government is working on improving Nepal's sovereign credit rating to show that Nepal is more open to foreign investment. Nepal is also making it easier for investors to take back profits.

**Hydropower and Energy**

Nepal has plans for clean energy development, including hydropower. Nepal has agreements with India, Bangladesh, and China to sell surplus energy.

**Political Stability**

Nepal's government acknowledges that there is political instability, but it emphasizes that the country has stable policies.

**Addressing Rumors**

The government denies rumors that big investors are reluctant to invest in Nepal because of the current political coalition.

**Geopolitical Factors**

Nepal welcomes legal investment from all countries and wants to ensure that investments are not targeted against any particular country.
summary: Nepal's third Investment Summit aims to attract foreign investment, presenting success stories and implementing reforms to enhance its investment-friendly environment, despite concerns about geopolitical influences and political instability.

title: Directly electing the Prime Minister and Chief Ministers could end political instability. This would give voters more control and accountability.
content:
**Political Instability in Nepal**

* Political parties are competing unfairly to control provincial governments, causing public frustration.
* Leaders blame the mixed electoral system for instability, but political ambition and corruption may be the real causes.
* Some argue for a two-party system, but there is no guarantee it would bring stability.
* The mixed electoral system has increased representation of marginalized groups, but some leaders misuse it for personal gain.
* Direct election of the prime minister and chief ministers is proposed as a solution for stability.

**Provinces and Decentralization**

* Provinces have adopted the same problematic parliamentary system as the central government.
* Local units, which use a different system, have more stability.
* Some claim provinces are unnecessary, but others argue they are essential for inclusivity.
* Provinces have failed to deliver on promises of decentralization and improvement of services.
* Madhesh Province has experienced corruption and lack of inclusivity, despite being led by Madheshi parties.

**New Parties in Madhesh**

* Janamat Party and Nagarik Unmukti Party have emerged, challenging established Madheshi parties.
* Janamat focuses on fighting discrimination and bad governance, while Nagarik Unmukti represents the interests of the Tharu community.
* Rastriya Swatantra Party prioritizes good governance and has gained support in hill areas.
summary: Nepali politics has been marred by unhealthy power struggles within provincial governments, leading to public frustration and accusations that the electoral system perpetuates instability. Political analyst Tula Narayan Shah advocates for direct election of executive heads in both provinces and the center, arguing that it would foster stability. Additionally, the poor performance of provinces and the emergence of new political parties in Madhesh reflect public dissatisfaction with the ruling elite and highlight ongoing issues of discrimination and governance.

title: I support a fully proportional representation system with a 5% threshold.
content:
**Nepal's Electoral System**

**Concerns:**
* Nepali Congress leaders believe the mixed electoral system is unstable, leading to hung parliaments.

**Former Election Commissioner's Views:**
* The success of an electoral system depends on its users, not its design.
* Nepal's mixed system was implemented after the 2006 People's Movement to ensure representation for historically underrepresented groups.
* The system has been successful in increasing representation, but leaders have misused the proportional representation (PR) system.

**Anomalies in the Mixed System:**
* Leaders have promoted family members and loyalists in PR seats.
* The names of influential people have been placed at the top of PR lists to increase election chances.

**Representation of Marginalised Groups:**
* Women have gained representation, but their presence in decision-making positions is still low.
* Dalits have increased representation, but it is not proportional to their population.

**Proposed Solutions:**
* Former Commissioner suggests a fully proportional representation (PR) system.
* Candidates should be selected through primaries to reduce leader influence.
* The PR system should be implemented at the local level.
* Increase the threshold to qualify for PR votes to ensure bigger parties secure more seats.

**Other Considerations:**
* Voting rights for Nepalis abroad is feasible, but leaders may resist due to unpredictable election outcomes.
* Online voting is technically possible to connect voters abroad to their local booths.
summary: Amidst political instability, Nepali Congress and CPN-UML leaders advocate for electoral system reform, with former election commissioner Neel Kantha Uprety emphasizing the need for an inclusive, fully proportional representation system that minimizes leader manipulation.

title: **Muluki Ain** is a set of laws in Nepal that defines acceptable behaviours, punishments, and rights.
content:
**Muluki Ain, Nepal's Historic Legal Code**

The Muluki Ain, translated by Heidelberg University, provides valuable insights into Nepal's history. It established a legal system that recognized the rule of law and defended against arbitrary rulings.

While the Muluki Ain reflected the existing caste system, it aimed to be fair. It emphasized that punishments should be equal for all, regardless of caste. The code also acknowledged the need for social reforms and intended to address embedded injustices.

The Muluki Ain was a comprehensive document that covered various aspects of life, including religious customs and social traditions. Despite its limitations, it played a significant role in Nepal's legal and social development.
summary: The 1854 Muluki Ain, translated by Heidelberg University, rationalized Nepal's legal system, formalized caste-based social norms while recognizing the need for reform, and established rule of law.

title:
**Misleading News**

Misleading news is information presented as true but contains distortions or omissions designed to deceive.

**Causes:**
- Biased sources
- Incomplete or inaccurate reporting
- Sensationalism
- Deliberate manipulation

**Effects:**
- Public confusion and misunderstanding
- Loss of trust in media
- Damage to reputations
- Social division and conflict

**How to avoid:**
- Check multiple sources
- Consider bias and motivations
- Look for supporting evidence
- Be skeptical of sensationalism
content:
A news report claimed Sinohydro Corporation, a Chinese contractor for the Melamchi Water Supply Project, did not pay for materials used in constructing the Ambathan dam in Helambu, Nepal. Sinohydro denies this, stating:

* They acquired materials legally from local vendors, suppliers, and recycled previously excavated materials.
* They have paid all vendors and suppliers in full.
* Documents supporting these transactions are available.

Sinohydro believes the news report is misleading and should be corrected.
summary: Sinohydro denies owing taxes on resources used in Helambu project, claiming it legally sourced materials and paid local suppliers.

title: Misunderstanding occurs when two or more people have different expectations or interpretations of a situation. It can be caused by miscommunication, lack of clarity, or biased thinking. Misunderstandings can lead to conflict and damaged relationships, but they can also be resolved through open communication and a willingness to listen and understand each other's perspectives.
content:
**Japan Needs Nepalese Workers**

Japan is facing a labor shortage and is looking to Nepal for workers in 14 industries.

**Misunderstandings About the Agreement**

* The agreement does not require government-to-government hiring.
* The Japanese government does not interfere in the private job market.
* Private recruiting agencies are not banned from participating in the process of sending and accepting workers.
* Workers may have to pay for their own airfare, insurance, and medical exam.

**Help for Nepali Workers**

* Nepali workers are encouraged to find their own jobs in the Japanese labor market.
* Japan and Nepal are working to address issues with recruitment agencies.
* Nepal has signed similar agreements with other South Asian countries.

**Conclusion**

The Embassy of Japan hopes this information will help Nepalese workers understand the agreement and find jobs in Japan.
summary: Japan and Nepal agreed to a Memorandum of Cooperation in 2019 to facilitate the employment of Nepalis as Specified Skilled Workers (SSW) in Japan without government intervention, allowing private agencies to assist with job placement and expenses varying by employment contract.

title: chhaupadi-persists
content: While feminine issues are addressed every now and then, not everything is taken seriously, and the unspoken issues go unnoticed. Here, I’m not only addressing the horrendous issue of Chhaupadi itself but also speaking of those women and girls who fall prey to this absurd menstrual practice.Ever thought what travelling back in time would feel like? Many in Nepal do not have to imagine, as such old and evil practises continue to occur in the 21st century!Chhaupadi is a flawed tradition connected to the taboo surrounding menstruation that prohibits Hindu menstruators from participating in normal family activities while on their period, as they are considered impure. Although it is said to be practised in the rural part of the country, it does exist in urban areas, too. Going back to its roots, we could perhaps rationalise that women were asked to stay cautious when menstruating because humans were closely surrounded by wildlife. The stench of blood during their period may have made them more vulnerable to attacks from these animals. But even this absurd line of thought doesn't make much sense anymore. The practise was made illegal in 2005, but cases related to it were reported as recent as 2019. News headlines vouched for fatalities on this account. But why are there such trivial punishments for such an offence? Shouldn’t the punishments be rethought to strongly discourage Chhaupadi altogether?Moreover, the reported cases are just the tip of the iceberg. The more you look into it, there are bound to be cases that have gone unreported because nothing immediately tragic occurred. This letter is a call for all of us to come together to fight this social plague. While the legal implications of such an offence are ambiguous, let's collectively decide that the societal implications of it will be grave. Let's refuse to accept such atrocities for our mothers, sisters and, above all, ourselves.Gauri Tandon, via email
